pullrequest.title: [Citadel] Replace `use_parent_model_frame` element with `//axis/xyz/@expressed_in` attribute in sdf 1.7

pull_request.title: [Citadel] Replace `use_parent_model_frame` element with `//axis/xyz/@expressed_in` attribute in sdf 1.7

update.description:
This pull request builds on both ~~pull request #588~~ and ~~pull request #580~~. It is targeted at `spec_1.7_9` (pr #588) and currently includes the changes to the Converter from pr #580. Once those PR's are merged, this will be simply targeted at default.

This replaces the `//axis/use_parent_model_frame` boolean elements with `//axis/xyz/@expressed_in` string elements that store the name of a frame in which the joint axis is expressed. During conversion from sdf 1.6 -> 1.7, any `use_parent_model_frame` element with a true value is mapped to an `//axis/xyz/@expressed_in` attribute with value `__model__`, corresponding to the name of the model frame in the [sdf frame semantics proposal](http://sdformat.org/tutorials?tut=pose_frame_semantics_proposal&cat=pose_semantics_docs&#7-replace-joint-axis-use_parent_model_frame-with-joint-axis-xyz-expressed_in).

It adds new API's to the `sdf::JointAxis` class and deprecates the API's related to `use_parent_model_frame`.

After some experimenting with xml stylesheets, I decided to include an `xslt` that is equivalent to the `1_6.convert` file. It is provided for reference but is not used by libsdformat or tested by the built-in tests.

I also made some minor formatting adjustments to the migration guide.

update.description:
This pull request builds on both ~~pull request #588~~ and ~~pull request #580~~. It is targeted at `spec_1.7_9` (pr #588) and currently includes the changes to the Converter from pr #580. Once those PR's are merged, this will be simply targeted at default.

This replaces the `//axis/use_parent_model_frame` boolean elements with `//axis/xyz/@expressed_in` string elements that store the name of a frame in which the joint axis is expressed. During conversion from sdf 1.6 -> 1.7, any `use_parent_model_frame` element with a true value is mapped to an `//axis/xyz/@expressed_in` attribute with value `__model__`, corresponding to the name of the model frame in the [sdf frame semantics proposal](http://sdformat.org/tutorials?tut=pose_frame_semantics_proposal&cat=pose_semantics_docs&#7-replace-joint-axis-use_parent_model_frame-with-joint-axis-xyz-expressed_in).

It adds new API's to the `sdf::JointAxis` class and deprecates the API's related to `use_parent_model_frame`.

After some experimenting with xml stylesheets, I decided to include an `xslt` that is equivalent to the `1_6.convert` file. It is provided for reference but is not used by libsdformat or tested by the built-in tests.

I also made some minor formatting adjustments to the migration guide.

content.raw: I don't want to merge it all at once, so I think we can merge these changes to the spec and relevant DOM accessors first and add in the `ResolvePose` functionality later with the rest of frame semantics
content.html: I don't want to merge it all at once, so I think we can merge these changes to the spec and relevant DOM accessors first and add in the ResolvePose functionality later with the rest of frame semantics

content.html: Okay, I guess what I'm asking is, since @expressed_in depends on frame semantics, if we would merge this to default without the frame semantics functionality in default first.

pull_request.title: [Citadel] Replace `use_parent_model_frame` element with `//axis/xyz/@expressed_in` attribute in sdf 1.7

pullrequest.title: [Citadel] Replace `use_parent_model_frame` element with `//axis/xyz/@expressed_in` attribute in sdf 1.7

content.raw:
My concern is that a model could be inconsistent if we allow the `use_parent_model_frame` tag to co-exist with `//axis/xyz/@expressed_in`. What does it mean if `//axis/use_parent_model_frame = 'true'` and `//axis/xyz/@expressed_in` is set to another frame (such as `'joint'`)?

The `JointAxis::UseParentModelFrame()` functions are deprecated, but `JointAxis` is still trying to read the `use_parent_model_frame` element (see [line 153](#!/osrf/sdformat/src/dbee697d1343dfd47040a7f02d00a33b378321fb/src/JointAxis.cc#lines-152:154) but it won't find it, so it will default to `false`.

I'd rather not allow for inconsistency in the model.
content.html:
My concern is that a model could be inconsistent if we allow the use_parent_model_frame tag to co-exist with //axis/xyz/@expressed_in. What does it mean if //axis/use_parent_model_frame = 'true' and //axis/xyz/@expressed_in is set to another frame (such as 'joint')?

The JointAxis::UseParentModelFrame() functions are deprecated, but JointAxis is still trying to read the use_parent_model_frame element (see line 153 but it won't find it, so it will default to false.

I'd rather not allow for inconsistency in the model.

pull_request.title: [Citadel] Replace `use_parent_model_frame` element with `//axis/xyz/@expressed_in` attribute in sdf 1.7

pullrequest.title: [Citadel] Replace `use_parent_model_frame` element with `//axis/xyz/@expressed_in` attribute in sdf 1.7

content.raw: The conversion from `//axis/use_parent_model_frame` to `//axis/xyz/@expressed_in` look good to me, but I'm concerned existing code that queries `use_parent_model_frame` either directly via an `sdf::ElementPtr` or through the DOM. Would it be okay if we deprecate `use_parent_model_frame` in 1.7 but not remove it until the next version?
content.html: The conversion from //axis/use_parent_model_frame to //axis/xyz/@expressed_in look good to me, but I'm concerned existing code that queries use_parent_model_frame either directly via an sdf::ElementPtr or through the DOM. Would it be okay if we deprecate use_parent_model_frame in 1.7 but not remove it until the next version?

pull_request.title: [Citadel] Replace `use_parent_model_frame` element with `//axis/xyz/@expressed_in` attribute in sdf 1.7

pullrequest.title: [Citadel] Replace `use_parent_model_frame` element with `//axis/xyz/@expressed_in` attribute in sdf 1.7

content.raw: Can you add a comment here stating that this file is here only for reference and that it's not currently used by libsdformat?
content.html: Can you add a comment here stating that this file is here only for reference and that it's not currently used by libsdformat?

pull_request.title: [Citadel] Replace `use_parent_model_frame` element with `//axis/xyz/@expressed_in` attribute in sdf 1.7

update.description:
This pull request builds on both pull request #588 and pull request #580. It is targeted at `spec_1.7_9` (pr #588) and currently includes the changes to the Converter from pr #580. Once those PR's are merged, this will be simply targeted at default.

This replaces the `//axis/use_parent_model_frame` boolean elements with `//axis/xyz/@expressed_in` string elements that store the name of a frame in which the joint axis is expressed. During conversion from sdf 1.6 -> 1.7, any `use_parent_model_frame` element with a true value is mapped to an `//axis/xyz/@expressed_in` attribute with value `__model__`, corresponding to the name of the model frame in the [sdf frame semantics proposal](http://sdformat.org/tutorials?tut=pose_frame_semantics_proposal&cat=pose_semantics_docs&#7-replace-joint-axis-use_parent_model_frame-with-joint-axis-xyz-expressed_in).

It adds new API's to the `sdf::JointAxis` class and deprecates the API's related to `use_parent_model_frame`.

After some experimenting with xml stylesheets, I decided to include an `xslt` that is equivalent to the `1_6.convert` file. It is provided for reference but is not used by libsdformat or tested by the built-in tests.

I also made some minor formatting adjustments to the migration guide.
update.title: Replace `use_parent_model_frame` element with `//axis/xyz/@expressed_in` attribute in sdf 1.7
